answers.answer: i say better safe than sorry...i only wish i could have got them...all the babies who's mother's were able to get the steroid shots moved through the NICU (and got of the vent, and had less severe brain bleeds if any, and didn't have ROP so severe) quicker thank Brady.  Of course, he was the youngest one there...But still...I hear the steroids help a lot.

When I became 90% effaced at 29wks they gave me steriods for lung development just incase I went into preterm labor.  I didn't really consider whether or not there could/would be negative effects, I just took it.Unless I had a really good reason not to, I would probably do it again.good luck..

Tired my first son was born at 32 weeks, as far as I was aware to give baby the best chance with lung development you need two shots of the steriods in the twelve hours prior to birth, that is what I got and my baby did not need any help with his breathing at birth. I was considered higher risk for my second pregnany but steriods were never suggested. I did have to have a planned c seation at 37 weeks and two days prior I had an amnio to check for lung maturity, they would have given me steriods at that point if necessary but the tests came back that baby's lungs were mature. If it makes you feel better and there are no risks or side effects with the steroids then why not.Annice; I had the steroid shots, my son had no breathing problems at birth and was not ventilated but he still had grade three brain bleeds, I know another mom who's baby was born at 30 weeks, no steroids and was ventilated and he did just fine and had no brain bleeds. Unfortunately the whole brain bleed issue is just a case of bad luck sometimes. But I agree preemies do seem to, in general, have a better outcome when the mom got the steroids.
I wonder why they bother with an amnio to check for lung development if the steroids are safe to take??

I supposed I can always make this decision when the time comes. If I have absolutely no signs of problems (no protein in urine, no BP problems, etc...) i can discuss it with him. Last time I had nearly a week between him suspecting PE and it getting so bad that they had to get the baby out. Even if there's more rapid onset, I imagine I would have at least 12 hours.

I had hypertension with both pregnancies-  Taylor was born at 36 weeks, and was fully developed-  my water broke with her at 36 weeks...  with Colten I had NO problems with my pregnancy until about 34 weeks, then the hypertension came back--- at 37 weeks exactly my doctor did the c-section, but he had me coming to see him to monitor my BP every other day-  he never mentioned steriods,  but maybe that is because Taylor was fine at 36 weeks?!  I don't know,  but if you doc seems okay with it, and you trust him,  I would do it....   my doctor said to come prepaired every time that he would take me into surgery and deliver the baby, if my BP got too high,  he said he'd rather have the baby out and in intensive care, then risk my life....  it never got to that....  so I wouldn't even risk it, if I had that decision to make, I guess...  it does make you wonder about why the amnio, if it is just safe to do the steroids?

I got my shots at 27 weeks, and my son was not born until 31 weeks. The neonatologist said that the steroids made all the difference in the world....I say go for it, before it is too late for them to help :-) I would not wait for "12 hrs before delivery"....you have no idea what kind of emergency could arise. If your doc thinks it is a good idea, given your history, I would recommend doing it.

I know you can still get the bleeds w the steroids and no bleeds without them, but I did hear they COULD help.  I think it's defintely worth it for all of the other things they could help with though.Again, your son is such an inspiration to us!  I am going to message you soon...when I'm not tired...bc things are just starting to get interesting and  i have developmental questions for              you!

tired i was put on bedrest with my son 10 years ago (almost 11).  started at 30 weeks and i was given shots for his lungs.  he was born at 37 weeks perfect as can be.with addison i had a perfect pg.  no problems at all.  id swell a bit here and there but was careful with my diet.  without any warning my water broke at 34w6d.  she was perfect but who knew?   im afraid that my next would be a bit early too but how do you know?  there is a test they do now from a blood draw that can determine if the baby is going to come in the next few weeks.  i suppose if they start that at around 30-32 weeks it can help to determine if it will be needed.i dont know anything in regards to effects it can have, maybe do some research but i think if its needed id do it.  lets hope you are not one of the moms that keeps having early babies!

i wouldn't have an early baby because of her- it would be because of my complications (althought it did begin to affect her in weight gain and such which is why they did the c-section at 36 weeks 0 days).i appreciate all of your input. Obviously, i wouldn't hesitate at all if there were signs of a problem. i was wondering about giving them preemptively when all seems to be going well. Your stories convinced me to go ahead and do it. Now I'm just wondering why they bother with amnios to test for lung maturity if steroids have no negative effects. Or is that only done in cases where waiting is an option? I think they didn't bother last time because waiting wasn't an option. It's interesting- the morning i found out i had to devliver, i asked the dr about dd's lungs, since we were only 36 weeks. He said that he wasn't concerned because babies in distress at that stage in pregnancy have their lungs mature faster in response. I don't know if that's the reason why, but dd had absolutely no problems with her lungs (thank God!).

Its not common to preemptively give steroids.  I'm not going to go so far as to say its never done, but its more commonly done for history of sudden, unexpected and repeated preterm delivery than PIH.    There is usually, but not always, some warning of impending preeclampsia or PIH.  Steroids only have to be on board for 24 hours to be effective.Steroids are not usually given after 34 weeks.   If your baby is born after 34 weeks, steroids are not proven to be of much help.  Most babies born at or after 34 weeks eventually do very well, with or without steriods.Steroids are proven to be of benefit to babies born prior to 34 weeks.I don't think they will harm anything, and if your doctor feels steroids will be beneficial in your particular case, I certainly couldn't argue.  I'm not a physician.  I'm not sure I follow the reasoning behind giving them at 34 weeks, but they shouldn't hurt anything to receive them.

question: I had an appointment today, and my OB mentioned that he will give me steroids at 34 weeks as a preemptive measure in case I develop preeclampsia again. Is he being overcautious? He said there are no potential negative effects on the baby. I know my risks are not as high as last time, but I can't help but feel like he thinks there's a decent chance of complications again. He's treating me as high-risk and seeing me more frequently than in my last pregnancy. He's taking measurements at each u/s and mentioned that studies show that measure can indicate potential problems before the hypertension sets in. So far he's always made it a point to mention that the baby's measurements are very good.Anyone get steroids for lung development preemptively? I hate to say it, but from the beginning of this pregnancy I've had a feeling something will go wrong. I don't get these premonitions often, but when I do, they're usually right. With my last pregnancy, i KNEW that i was going to have problems and that I'd have the baby before my shower. I was right. I can't shake that feeling this time, and this is kinda reaffirming my underlying fears.by the way, it's not that I don't trust him. I trust him with my life. He is seeing me every 2-3 weeks, and taking very good care of me. It does give me some peace of mind. I guess I want to know if this is typical...
title: preemptive steroids??
